article.title: complementary colour
article.p:
complementary colour
, one of a pair of colours that are opposite each other on the traditional colour wheel.

The complementary colour to one of the primary hues—red, yellow, and blue—is the mixture of the other two; complementary to red, for example, is green, which is blue mixed with yellow. When complementary pairs are juxtaposed, mutual enhancement of colour intensity results. For instance, red and green are more intense when they are next to one another than either would be if surrounded by harmonious hues. The 19th-century physicist
Michel-Eugène Chevreul
referred to this mutual exaltation of opposites as the law of simultaneous contrast.
